context: [3] The mean (SD) relative humidity was 34.0% (2.2%) and remained relatively constant throughout the field study. [4] The two-way vehicle count during the experiment was 4179 (17:00 to 18:00 h) and 2958 (18:00 to 19:00 h). [1] The results of the BTEX ambient air concentration measurements are given in table 1. [2] The benzene level based on the time period of the study and the ethylbenzene results are semiquantitative because the analyte was detected at a level above the linear response of calibration curve. [1] The detection limits of the assay were estimated at 0.5 ng/ml based on a signal:noise ratio of 3. Precision, estimated using the ratio between D8 toluene:D10 ethylbenzene and D10 ethylbenzene:D10 o-xylene from all samples, was 6.9% RSD and 4.9% RSD respectively. [2] Accuracy at 0.5 ng/ml was +2.3%, âˆ’3.5%, âˆ’5.6%, âˆ’7.5% and âˆ’4.2% for benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, m/p-xylene and o-xylene, respectively. [3] A GC-MS chromatogram of an exercising subject is shown in fig 1 containing BTEX and deuterated standards.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene is identified as an analyte in the measurement of BTEX (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene) ambient air concentrations. The results indicate that ethylbenzene was detected at levels above the calibration curve's linear response, suggesting its significance as a target compound in air quality assessments. However, the relationship is primarily focused on its role as a measured substance rather than any deeper interaction or functional significance.
